attributes.title: The work of district nursing teams in the United Kingdom: effects of policy, practice and research on role: a scoping review protocol.

q1.value: The work of district nursing teams in the United Kingdom: effects of policy, practice and research on role: a scoping review protocol.

q2.value: Bruce Harper-McDonald, Dr. Janet Hanley, Dr. Richard G Kyle

q3.value:
A growing body of research highlights within acute hospital settings there is an invisibility in the work of nurses, where recognition that the prevailing focus on viewing the nurses role as a series of tasks is arbitrary, limited in scope and fails to acknowledge and appreciate the multivariate nature of nursing (1-3). However concurrently there is an international drive to move care into communities, it is timely to extend this research to invisible work of nurses within the community setting, where there is recognition, despite over three decades of policy, literature, research and expert opinion aiming to quantify and measure the work of district nursing teams, their work remains poorly defined, and the profession is described as the most invisible profession in the National Health Service (NHS) (6). It has been widely acknowledged the importance of exploring what this invisible work is, to fully appreciate the role of the district nurse (4-7). However this gap in knowledge is yet to be addressed.

In the absence of a prior systematic literature review or scoping review, the use of a scoping review methodology will provide the ideal opportunity to systematically approach reviewing all types of literature from a vast and complex base, synthesize this literature and provide a map of key concepts underpinning the nature of the phenomenon on the invisible work of district nurses (8-12). Completing this scoping review will help to provide an opportunity to summarise and map the existing literature base providing a valuable comprehensive overview for policy makers, managers and district nurses in practice. Additionally, this scoping review will aid identification of gaps in research and knowledge that will inform the direction of future empirical research. 

In order to systematically identify and map the literature in relation to the research topic a scoping review question was formed using the mnemonic PCC (13):

What effect has policy, practice and research had on influencing the work of district nursing teams in the United Kingdom making their work difficult to define, measure and manage?

Scoping Review Question Formation

Population: District nursing teams in the United Kingdom 
Concept: Define, measure and management of work
Context: Influencing factors from policy, practice development and research

This prospective scoping review protocol has been developed using the Joanna Briggs Institute methodology guidance for conducting a scoping review (see below Study Design) and then the protocol amended to adhere to the Centre for Open Science (OSF) pro formula for prospective protocol registration.

q4.value: This scoping review aims to systematically identify and map all available literature to answer the scoping review question above and therefore has no hypothesis.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The study design is a scoping review that aims to systematically approach mapping the evidence in relation to the challenges in defining the nature of district nurses work. With scoping reviews being a new and emerging methodology, these reviews have varied enormously in procedural and methodological rigour. In order to strengthen the rigour for this method Arskey and O’Malley (10) developed a framework for conducting scoping reviews and welcomed other researchers to advance this framework. Levac, Colquhoun and O’Brien (24) provided an extension to the framework and finally in 2015 the JBI furthered this framework and developed guidance on conducted a scoping review (13).  The JBI guidance on conducting a scoping review will guide this review (13). Illustrated below is how this prospective protocol maps to the JBI methodology:

	Step 1 – Defining and aligning the objective/s and question/s for the scoping review (see above Description).
	Step 2 – Developing and aligning the inclusion criteria with the objective/s and question/s (see below Data Collection Procedures (inclusion criteria) and see below Data Exclusion (exclusion criteria)).
	Step 3 – Describing the planned approach to evidence searching, selection, extraction, and charting (see below Data Collection Procedures).
	Step 4 – Searching for the evidence (see below Data Collection Procedures).
	Step 5 – Selecting the evidence (see below Data Collection Procedures).
	Step 6 – Extracting the evidence (see below Measured Variables for data charting process).
	Step 7 – Charting the evidence (see below Exploratory Analysis).
	Step 8 – Summarizing the evidence in relation to the objective/s and question/s (see below Exploratory Analysis).
	Step 9 – Consultation of information scientists, librarians, and/or experts (throughout)(see below Missing Data).

Additionally, to increase transparency of the scoping review a reporting checklist will be used, the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis extension for Scoping Reviews (PRIMSA-ScR), that is consistent with the JBI guidance (12, 14). Application of JBI guidance and PRISMA-ScR to this scoping review will ensure the review is transparent, rigorous and reliable (12). While subjectivity cannot be totally eliminated, providing this detailed prospective protocol has aimed to increase the transparency on the systematic approach applied to the scoping review. 

The scoping review will identify all sources of information that would address the scoping review question, including; primary research, systematic reviews, meta-analysis, guidelines, government policy and documents, websites and textbooks. Consistent with the JBI guidance a standard data extraction instrument will be used, described below, and there will be no critical appraisal or methodological assessment conducted, because the aim is to map all literature relevant to the scoping review question and not the best research evidence (10, 13, 15). If limits were applied based on quality of evidence it would affect the overall accuracy of the scoping review and would fail to provide a broad map highlighting gaps in knowledge. 

Due to the iterative nature of scoping reviews, search terms will be continuously developed. An initial search using AMED, CINAHL and Medline will be conducted, prior to finalising the prospective protocol, and initial returned results will be reviewed (title, abstract and keywords) until initial search terms are developed. It is anticipated additional search terms may be identified during the data charting process and if this is the case will be transparently reported in the final scoping review.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
As part of the data collection procedure (inclusion criteria) to identify all potentially relevant literature a comprehensive search strategy to identify both published and unpublished grey literature was prospectively developed as part of the scoping review protocol. This has seen a comprehensive four stage strategy being developed including; bibliographic database searching, ancestry search method, descendancy searching method and searching the grey literature (16). 

The first strategy will involve a search of the bibliographic databases, using the search terms developed as part of the initial searches. This will include the following bibliographic databases; CINAHL, ASSIA, Cochrane Library, Medline, PubMed and Google Scholar. Once the searches are performed, returned results will be exported to EndNote X9.2 reference management software, to manage the searches and identify and remove duplicates (10). The search terms will also be saved as alerts on the bibliographic databases so any new publications, published during the scoping review will be identified and considered for inclusion in the scoping review. Literature published in English will be considered for inclusion in the scoping review. Initially, literature published from 1990 to 2019 will be considered for inclusion. This date range was set as literature pre Community Care Act 1990 (25) is less likely to be relevant as the work of district nursing teams changed significantly at this time, although this change will be acknowledged in the review. The date range may be broadened following an iterative approach discussed below. 

The following are the initial search terms applied; district nurse, community nurse, community matron, health visitor, homecare nurse, community midwife, nurse, safe staffing, caseload profiling, caseload management, caseload analysis, workload analysis, workload tools, workload measurement tool, workforce planning, workforce measures, workload planning, community profiling, measure, community, primary care, district, home setting. Combinations of these search terms will be applied using Boolean operators, with search terms truncated for variation in spelling (for example: nurs*) and synonyms applied (18). At the onset, the search will be extended to include other community nursing professionals, for example health visitors, to scope if there is any transferable knowledge to the district nursing profession. 

The second strategy that will be applied to the search will involve hand-checking reference lists contained in returned results (ancestry method)(10, 15, 16). Additionally, the descendancy method will be applied, to determine additional seminal or pivotal sources to the review question. This will be achieved by searching forward to citation indexes of articles that have cited key seminal pieces (16).

The final strategy that will be applied to the search will be to locate unpublished grey literature, from professional bodies, expert opinion and government policies and publications. While these sources are more subjective and lower in quality, their inclusion may provide useful insights that would otherwise be missed with their exclusion (13). The search of the grey literature will be conducted via government and relevant professional bodies’ websites. Below is a list of the organisations to be included in the search for grey literature:

	Audit Scotland
	Department of Health (including NHS Improvement and NHS England)
	Information Services Division 
	Kings Fund 
	National Institute for Health and Care Excellence 
	Northern Ireland Department of Health 
	Nursing and Midwifery Council
	Queens Nursing Institute 
	Queens Nursing Institute Scotland 
	Royal College of Nursing 
	Scottish Government (including NHS Education for Scotland) 
	UK Parliament
	Welsh Government (including Welsh Audit Office and National Assembly for Wales)
	World Health Organisation 

Additionally, professional district nursing textbooks will also be considered as part of the search of the grey literature (16). To locate these textbooks a search of Google Scholar, the library catalogue at Edinburgh Napier University and the British Library catalogue (UK copyright library) will be conducted to identify texts relevant to the review question. 

The search strategy detailed above as part of data collection, was checked by an experienced subject librarian, at Edinburgh Napier University, to ensure it was comprehensive in breadth prior to the scoping review protocol being registered.

Following the search, described above, all identified citations will be uploaded to EndNote X9.2 reference management software. Titles, abstracts (or executive summaries in the grey literature) will be reviewed, and literature that meets the inclusion criteria will be retrieved in full and details recorded using the predefined Data Extraction Instrument, described below. If studies that do not meet the inclusion criteria are identified, they will be excluded, and in line with JBI guidance, the reason for exclusion will be provided in the final review (13).

q13.value: The sample/number of included studies to be included in this scoping review is unknown. However in the final scoping review the selection of sources will be described and presented using a PRISMA Flow Diagram (23).

q15.value:
Initially, the date range 1990-2019 will be applied, however due to the broad scope of this review, in line with accepted practices, studies more easily obtainable will be prioritised (8). Therefore pre-1990 literature may be accessed however will be limited and prioritised to seminal pieces. For the purposes of this scoping review seminal has been defined as policy or research of significance to the scoping review question, and will be transparently reported in the final scoping review. Only studies published in English will be considered for inclusion in this scoping review. 

Once searches are conducted on bibliographic databases alerts will be set to ensure any new publications, published during the scoping review period will be identified and considered for inclusion in this scoping review. Additionally, the use of more advanced literature searching skills will be employed (17-18), with the use of social media also incorporated into the search strategy, including Facebook and Twitter. This will aid keeping abreast of newly published grey literature during the scoping review period. This will be achieved by following relevant professional organisations, governments and NHS trusts as well as following conference proceedings. Any additional sources identified using this strategy will be transparently reported in the final scoping review. These methods will be applied to ensure data collection is ongoing until the scoping review is completed and submitted for publication, estimated to be in the spring/summer of 2020.

question.value: As part of the data charting process (also referred to as charting the data) a data extraction form has been jointly developed as part of this protocol, using the instrument developed as part of the JBI guidance and modified to fit the nature of this review, which includes all types of literature (13). This extraction instrument captures specific details including; bibliographic details, literature type, population/sample, methodology, key findings, any gaps identified and relevance to the scoping review question.

q22.value: Exclusion terms will be kept to a minimum due to the broad scope of the search for the scoping review (13). However exclusions will be applied to literature not written in English and the work of nurses within the hospital setting, including, day hospitals, outpatients or nurse specialists working within hospitals. These exclusion will be applied, not only due to other researchers researching this group of nurses (1-3), but because it is beyond the aim of this scoping review which is considering work of nurses in the community. However, as highlighted above, the search will be extended to include other community nursing professionals, for example health visitors, to scope if there is any transferable knowledge to the district nursing profession.  Additionally, as mentioned above, in line with accepted practices, studies more easily obtainable will be prioritised (8). Therefore pre-millennium literature will be limited to easily obtainable or seminal pieces and those not easily obtainable will be excluded.

q23.value:
Consistent with JBI guidance, the use of consultation with scientists (experienced researchers), subject librarian and experts will be included to this scoping review (13). The inclusion of consultation will aim to provide an important strategy to validate and inform the scoping review findings and ensure no important concepts are omitted from the review. Bibliographic details including type and purpose of informant in the consultation process is detailed below:

Type of informant and purpose:
 
Informant 1	
Subject Librarian (specialising in Health and Social Care). 	
	Accuracy of protocol and support development of inclusion and exclusion criteria. 
	Support locating and accessing, non-readily available seminal literature.

Informant 2	
Professional Expert (retired District Nurse Team Leader from 1987-2016)	
	Use of professional practice experience and knowledge to confirm accuracy of context and reporting of findings. 
	Ensuring no concepts missed and offer additional detail and insights.

Informant 3	
Subject Expert (Queens Nursing Institute Scotland Historian)	
	Use of subject knowledge to confirm accuracy of context and reporting of findings. Ensuring no concepts missed and offer additional detail and insights.
Incorporation of the consultation stage will provide an important strategy to help ensure an accurate history is reported and no important information missed. This will help address the poorly recorded historiography of the district nursing profession (19). In the event of any disagreement in the findings this would be solved by consensus, returning to the literature or by involving a third reviewer (13).  To ensure the transparency of the consultation stage each informant will be asked to complete a general feedback form on the scoping review, illustrated in the attached scoping review protocol.

q24.value: Once all results have been charted using the data extraction instrument, defined above, a summary of all sources will be recorded using Microsoft Excel, illustrated in the attached scoping review protocol. This will then support the use of thematic/concept mapping to synthesise the results. This will enable identification of key concepts and relationships between research, policy, practice development and expert opinion summarised and organised in thematic headings (20-22). This strategy will be applied to ensure all results following data extraction are considered, not missed, and aid identification of key themes, to support the reporting of a heterogeneous literature base (22).

q25.value:
It would be important to acknowledge while in a systematic literature review deviation from a protocol is rare, due to the iterative nature of a scoping review modifications are possible, and likely, for example extending the search terms, described above, although if changes are required to this protocol this will be transparently reported in the final scoping review (9, 13, 15).

registration_responses.q8.question:
The study design is a scoping review that aims to systematically approach mapping the evidence in relation to the challenges in defining the nature of district nurses work. With scoping reviews being a new and emerging methodology, these reviews have varied enormously in procedural and methodological rigour. In order to strengthen the rigour for this method Arskey and O’Malley (10) developed a framework for conducting scoping reviews and welcomed other researchers to advance this framework. Levac, Colquhoun and O’Brien (24) provided an extension to the framework and finally in 2015 the JBI furthered this framework and developed guidance on conducted a scoping review (13).  The JBI guidance on conducting a scoping review will guide this review (13). Illustrated below is how this prospective protocol maps to the JBI methodology:

	Step 1 – Defining and aligning the objective/s and question/s for the scoping review (see above Description).
	Step 2 – Developing and aligning the inclusion criteria with the objective/s and question/s (see below Data Collection Procedures (inclusion criteria) and see below Data Exclusion (exclusion criteria)).
	Step 3 – Describing the planned approach to evidence searching, selection, extraction, and charting (see below Data Collection Procedures).
	Step 4 – Searching for the evidence (see below Data Collection Procedures).
	Step 5 – Selecting the evidence (see below Data Collection Procedures).
	Step 6 – Extracting the evidence (see below Measured Variables for data charting process).
	Step 7 – Charting the evidence (see below Exploratory Analysis).
	Step 8 – Summarizing the evidence in relation to the objective/s and question/s (see below Exploratory Analysis).
	Step 9 – Consultation of information scientists, librarians, and/or experts (throughout)(see below Missing Data).

Additionally, to increase transparency of the scoping review a reporting checklist will be used, the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis extension for Scoping Reviews (PRIMSA-ScR), that is consistent with the JBI guidance (12, 14). Application of JBI guidance and PRISMA-ScR to this scoping review will ensure the review is transparent, rigorous and reliable (12). While subjectivity cannot be totally eliminated, providing this detailed prospective protocol has aimed to increase the transparency on the systematic approach applied to the scoping review. 

The scoping review will identify all sources of information that would address the scoping review question, including; primary research, systematic reviews, meta-analysis, guidelines, government policy and documents, websites and textbooks. Consistent with the JBI guidance a standard data extraction instrument will be used, described below, and there will be no critical appraisal or methodological assessment conducted, because the aim is to map all literature relevant to the scoping review question and not the best research evidence (10, 13, 15). If limits were applied based on quality of evidence it would affect the overall accuracy of the scoping review and would fail to provide a broad map highlighting gaps in knowledge. 

Due to the iterative nature of scoping reviews, search terms will be continuously developed. An initial search using AMED, CINAHL and Medline will be conducted, prior to finalising the prospective protocol, and initial returned results will be reviewed (title, abstract and keywords) until initial search terms are developed. It is anticipated additional search terms may be identified during the data charting process and if this is the case will be transparently reported in the final scoping review.
registration_responses.q12.question:
As part of the data collection procedure (inclusion criteria) to identify all potentially relevant literature a comprehensive search strategy to identify both published and unpublished grey literature was prospectively developed as part of the scoping review protocol. This has seen a comprehensive four stage strategy being developed including; bibliographic database searching, ancestry search method, descendancy searching method and searching the grey literature (16). 

The first strategy will involve a search of the bibliographic databases, using the search terms developed as part of the initial searches. This will include the following bibliographic databases; CINAHL, ASSIA, Cochrane Library, Medline, PubMed and Google Scholar. Once the searches are performed, returned results will be exported to EndNote X9.2 reference management software, to manage the searches and identify and remove duplicates (10). The search terms will also be saved as alerts on the bibliographic databases so any new publications, published during the scoping review will be identified and considered for inclusion in the scoping review. Literature published in English will be considered for inclusion in the scoping review. Initially, literature published from 1990 to 2019 will be considered for inclusion. This date range was set as literature pre Community Care Act 1990 (25) is less likely to be relevant as the work of district nursing teams changed significantly at this time, although this change will be acknowledged in the review. The date range may be broadened following an iterative approach discussed below. 

The following are the initial search terms applied; district nurse, community nurse, community matron, health visitor, homecare nurse, community midwife, nurse, safe staffing, caseload profiling, caseload management, caseload analysis, workload analysis, workload tools, workload measurement tool, workforce planning, workforce measures, workload planning, community profiling, measure, community, primary care, district, home setting. Combinations of these search terms will be applied using Boolean operators, with search terms truncated for variation in spelling (for example: nurs*) and synonyms applied (18). At the onset, the search will be extended to include other community nursing professionals, for example health visitors, to scope if there is any transferable knowledge to the district nursing profession. 

The second strategy that will be applied to the search will involve hand-checking reference lists contained in returned results (ancestry method)(10, 15, 16). Additionally, the descendancy method will be applied, to determine additional seminal or pivotal sources to the review question. This will be achieved by searching forward to citation indexes of articles that have cited key seminal pieces (16).

The final strategy that will be applied to the search will be to locate unpublished grey literature, from professional bodies, expert opinion and government policies and publications. While these sources are more subjective and lower in quality, their inclusion may provide useful insights that would otherwise be missed with their exclusion (13). The search of the grey literature will be conducted via government and relevant professional bodies’ websites. Below is a list of the organisations to be included in the search for grey literature:

	Audit Scotland
	Department of Health (including NHS Improvement and NHS England)
	Information Services Division 
	Kings Fund 
	National Institute for Health and Care Excellence 
	Northern Ireland Department of Health 
	Nursing and Midwifery Council
	Queens Nursing Institute 
	Queens Nursing Institute Scotland 
	Royal College of Nursing 
	Scottish Government (including NHS Education for Scotland) 
	UK Parliament
	Welsh Government (including Welsh Audit Office and National Assembly for Wales)
	World Health Organisation 

Additionally, professional district nursing textbooks will also be considered as part of the search of the grey literature (16). To locate these textbooks a search of Google Scholar, the library catalogue at Edinburgh Napier University and the British Library catalogue (UK copyright library) will be conducted to identify texts relevant to the review question. 

The search strategy detailed above as part of data collection, was checked by an experienced subject librarian, at Edinburgh Napier University, to ensure it was comprehensive in breadth prior to the scoping review protocol being registered.

Following the search, described above, all identified citations will be uploaded to EndNote X9.2 reference management software. Titles, abstracts (or executive summaries in the grey literature) will be reviewed, and literature that meets the inclusion criteria will be retrieved in full and details recorded using the predefined Data Extraction Instrument, described below. If studies that do not meet the inclusion criteria are identified, they will be excluded, and in line with JBI guidance, the reason for exclusion will be provided in the final review (13).
registration_responses.q16.question: Not applicable
registration_responses.q17.question: As part of the data charting process (also referred to as charting the data) a data extraction form has been jointly developed as part of this protocol, using the instrument developed as part of the JBI guidance and modified to fit the nature of this review, which includes all types of literature (13). This extraction instrument captures specific details including; bibliographic details, literature type, population/sample, methodology, key findings, any gaps identified and relevance to the scoping review question.

attributes.title: Foreign Pressure and Public Opinion in Target States

q1.value: Foreign Pressure and Public Opinion in Target States

q2.value: Masaru Kohno | Gabriella R. Montinola | Matthew Winters

q9.value: Registration is after analysis of outcome data collected in one country, but prior to assignment of treatment and collection of data in remaining two countries of study.

q15.value: The international community considers how states govern within their borders an issue of legitimate concern. To influence states’ treatment of their citizens, other states and international organizations deploy a broad array of tools, including moral suasion and material assistance (or more commonly the threat of its withdrawal). Although the efficacy of foreign pressure is posited to depend on how publics in target states respond, research on the consequences of these instruments has focused mainly on their impact on target states’ behavior (e.g., Galtung 1967; Keck and Sikkink 1999; Peksen 2009). Consequently, evidence on the effect of foreign pressure on public opinion in target states is limited. The purpose of this project is to examine how two common tools of external influence—public condemnation and economic sanctions—affect domestic public opinion in states engaged on issues of concern to the international community. The literature provides competing arguments regarding the direction of these effects. On the one hand, foreign pressure is posited to provide citizens in target states with information and/or incentives that lead them to call for policy changes in line with the preferences of external actors (rationalist perspective). On the other hand, foreign pressure may be viewed by the domestic population in target states as threats to their national identity and sovereignty, inducing them to increase support for their governments’ policies and practices, an outcome referred to as the “rally-around-the-flag” or “backlash” effect. In this project, we focus on both forms of external pressure to understand not only how each instrument affects public opinion in target states but also to determine whether they have complementary or countervailing effects. We believe the arguments presented in the literature should apply to a relatively wide range of issues over which the international community might seek to exert influence and should generalize to a wide variety of political-economic contexts. Thus, our study focuses on three countries with different contexts--Indonesia, Myanmar, and Nepal.

q16.value: Our aim when collecting data for the first country in our study—Myanmar—was to test the following competing hypotheses derived from the literature: H1a: Information regarding foreign pressure will cause publics in target states to be more supportive of their government’s status quo policy (a backlash effect). H1b: Information regarding foreign pressure will cause publics in target states to be less supportive of their government’s status quo policy (rationalist perspective). Our initial analysis of data from Myanmar suggests that the different forms of pressure have countervailing effects: we found that information about criticism from foreign countries increased support for the government’s policy (a backlash effect). This positive effect, however, is attenuated among respondents informed of both criticism and the threat of aid sanctions, suggesting that criticism alone provokes threats to national identity and sovereignty, while the threat of aid sanctions generates concern over material interests. Based on our results from Myanmar, we thus expect the following hypotheses to be supported in data from Nepal and Indonesia: H2: Information regarding donors’ public criticism will cause publics in target states to be more supportive of their government’s status quo policy (a backlash effect). H3: Support for the target government’s status quo policy will be lower among individuals informed of both donor criticism and the threat of sanctions compared to individuals informed only of donor criticism (rationalist perspective). In addition to the hypotheses above, we will examine some of the theorized mechanisms linking information on foreign pressure and public opinion with our surveys to be conducted in Nepal and Indonesia. The rationalist perspective suggests, for example, that foreign pressure may influence public opinion by affecting beliefs regarding reputational and material costs. We thus hypothesize that: H4: Respondents informed of foreign pressure (both criticism and the threat of aid sanctions) will be more likely to expect their country to suffer reputational and material costs than those not informed of the foreign pressure. Alternatively, the literature on the backlash effect suggests that threats to national identity or sovereignty from outsiders are likely to elicit mistrust of outsiders’ motives. We thus hypothesize that: H5: Respondents informed of foreign pressure (both criticism and the threat of aid sanctions) are more likely to view such pressure as in the interest of foreign actors rather than in the interest of their own country compared to those not informed of foreign pressure.

q17.value: We will test these hypotheses with data from survey experiments. These experiments will be administered through computer-assisted personal interviews in the capital regions of Nepal and Indonesia. For each country, a representative sample of 1,000 subjects will be selected through a stratified random sampling method. Administrative units in the target regions will be randomly selected with probability proportional to the size of their populations. Sampling spots within each administrative unit will be randomly selected using a GIS-based technique. At the sampling spots, interviewers will use a spin-the-bottle technique to randomize the direction in which the survey will start. The interviewers will then select specific households from which survey respondents will be chosen using a skip interval. Once households are selected, the interviewers will use the last-birthday method to randomly select a respondent from among eligible individuals in the household. The selected subjects will then be randomly assigned to one of three groups as described below: Control: No information Treatment 1: Information on donor criticism Treatment 2: Information on donor criticism and threat of aid sanction

q27.value: Nikkei Research and local affiliates in Nepal and Indonesia

attributes.title: Collective Action and Solid Waste Collection in Zomba, Malawi

q1.value: Collective Action and Solid Waste Collection in Zomba, Malawi

q2.value: Jake Bowers | Nuole Chen | Boniface Dulani | Chris Grady | Matthew Winters

q5.value: We thank Zomba City Council and the Institute for Public Opinion and Research for their important contributions to this project.

q9.value: This study’s PAP was updated and uploaded to OSF before assignment of treatment. However, this study will be registered with EGAP after assignment of treatment, but before realization of outcomes.

q15.value: Many political jurisdictions around the world experience a vicious cycle in which too little taxes are collected and too few services are provided: when citizens do not pay taxes, governments cannot provide services; when governments do not provide services, citizens may perceive little reason to pay taxes. With Zomba, Malawi, we assess information-based strategies for improving the tax-and-service relationship between people and their government as a part of the EGAP Metaketa II series of projects. Fees and charges for city services are the main form of municipal revenue generation in Zomba. The City of Zomba requires that every homeowner pays a “city rate” (the equivalent of a property tax) to finance waste collection, street lighting, road maintenance, and other city services. Many households in the city, however, do not pay these city rates despite their desire for these municipal services. That lack of payment, along with a lack of capacity from the city, has resulted in certain wards of the city not receiving city services, which in turn has had effects on the public health and quality of life for the thousands of people living in those places. We have designed an information shock that aims to break the vicious cycle created by the lack of service provision and the lack of city rates payment. We expect a break in this cycle will produce a virtuous cycle that encourages more citizens to pay city rates and increases service provision by the city. Formalization of the relationship between the city government and its citizens should also increase citizens' trust and confidence in the city government, and perhaps government in general --- and trust and confidence, in turn, should enhance the ability of the government to serve the public.

q16.value: H0: The treatment will increase information about city rates among treatment households vs. control households. (Confirmatory hypothesis) H0a: The treatment will increase the salience of city rates among treatment households vs. control households. (Exploratory hypothesis) H1: The treatment will increase the intent to formalize among treatment households vs. control households. (Confirmatory hypothesis – formalization hypothesis family) H2: The treatment will increase formalization among treatment households vs. control households.(Confirmatory hypothesis – formalization hypothesis family) H3: The treatment will increase citizen's access to public services tightly related to the formalization process among treatment households vs. control households. (Confirmatory hypothesis) H4: The treatment will increase tax compliance among treatment households vs. control households.** (Confirmatory hypothesis – formalization hypothesis family) H5: The treatment will improve attitudes toward government among treatment households vs. control households. (Confirmatory hypothesis) In addition to overall improved attitudes toward government, we expect that residents may shift their attitudes about specific issues. We would like to explore which issues may be driving the overall attitudinal changes with the following exploratory hypotheses: H5A: The treatment will increase beliefs that the city deserves to collect taxes among treatment households vs. control households. (Exploratory hypothesis) H5B: The treatment will increase beliefs in city service capacity among treatment households vs. control households. (Exploratory hypothesis) H5C: The treatment will increase beliefs in city enforcement capacity among treatment households vs. control households. (Exploratory hypothesis) H5D: The treatment will increase satisfaction with city government among treatment households vs. control households. (Exploratory hypothesis) H5E: The treatment will increase beliefs that others pay city rates among treatment households compared to control households. (Exploratory hypothesis) Finally, the Taxation Metaketa Pre-analysis Plan proposes two secondary hypotheses: H6: The treatment will increase citizen's access to other public services among treatment households compared to control households. (Exploratory hypothesis) H7: The treatment will improve citizen's tax morale more generally and increases willingness to pay taxes not directly involved with the formalization process. (Exploratory hypothesis) Each of these hypotheses concerns the effect of the intervention bundle on treatment households. In addition to estimating the effect of the information intervention on treatment households, we will also estimate (1) the effect of diffusion from treatment households to control households, and (2) the effect of providing waste collection between the start of the intervention and the end of the intervention.

q17.value: We use e a field experiment to test our hypotheses. Data are collected from surveys and administrative data. Our study will take place in ~90 neighborhoods. Of these ~90 neighborhoods, 10 will be reserved as pure control neighborhoods where we will not administer the interventions. In each neighborhood, we will survey a randomly selected x% of household heads of owner-occupied homes such that the total sample size is n > 1800. In our study, we listed ~2300 homeowners and selected about 78% of each neighborhood. Within the ~80 neighborhoods where the information campaign will take place, half of the surveyed households will be assigned to the information campaign treatment, and the other half will serve as a control group. Households in the control condition will not receive the information bundle but will live in neighborhoods where other people are receiving the information bundle so they may be exposed to information about city rates indirectly from their neighbors and they will be exposed to the increase in service provision that is part of the study. We reserve 10 neighborhoods as a pure control group in order to estimate the spillover/diffusion of the information treatment from treated households in treatment neighborhoods to control households in treatment neighborhoods. No households in the pure control neighborhoods will receive the information campaign, but pure control households will be exposed to increased service provision.

q27.value: Researchers, Institute for Public Opinion and Research

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: We test to see whether a civil-society led information campaign about the structure of the formal legal sector and citizens’ legal rights under it is sufficient to (a) increase citizens’ desire to use formal legal mechanisms and (b) improve individuals’ perceptions of the justice system and inform citizens’ broader perceptions of the state and its legitimacy.

q17.value: We randomize the presence of the information campaign in 187 villages, blocking the randomization on cercle. We conduct baseline and endline household and elite surveys.

attributes.title: Bypass Aid and Local Accountability Informational Intervention II

q1.value: Bypass Aid and Local Accountability Informational Intervention II

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This project builds on a data collection effort conducted in Uganda in January 2016 (EGAP ID 20160113AB). We are interested in how information about the foreign funding and non-government implementation of local development projects affects the attitudes and behaviors of citizens in communities benefitting from foreign aid projects. We randomly assign Ugandan citizens living in the vicinity of a foreign-funded, non-government-implemented development project to receive information about these characteristics of the project, and we measure the impact of the information on (a) perceptions of the local development projects, (b) the willingness of citizens to hold politicians accountable, (c) the willingness of citizens to hold service providers accountable, and (d) the competence/legitimacy that citizens attach to government institutions.

q16.value: Project Perceptions: Political outsiders should prefer donor-funded and/or NGO-implemented projects and should generally perceive such projects in a more positive light as compared to projects that they think originate with the government. Electoral Accountability: If potential voters believe that they will have access to services delivered in a more impartial fashion, voters will no longer need to vote in the “right” way in order to secure access to services, we should see reduced intentions to vote for the incumbent. If the political incumbent is perceived as deserving credit for facilitating the presence of foreign-funded/non-governmental projects in the local community, then information about such projects may also increase support for the incumbent. Local Government Competence and Legitimacy: In a world where citizens give credit to governments for having secured local development projects from foreign and/or non-governmental actors, we expect to see perceptions of government competence improve when citizens learn about the foreign funding and/or non-state implementation. Service Accountability: If political outsiders view foreign-funded and/or NGO-implemented projects to be outside of traditional partisan networks, then they should be more likely to take action against project problems that they observe, whereas this will not necessarily true of political insiders.

q17.value: We will test our hypotheses related to providing information about the role of foreign funding and non-government implementation in local development projects by comparing responses to post-treatment questions and behaviors among subjects in the treatment arms where they learn about foreign funding (2 and 4) and/or non-government implementation (3 and 4) as against where they do not (1). We will look for heterogeneous effects by political insider/outsider status. If significant numbers of respondents have correct and certain priors, we will also run the analysis dropping these respondents.

q21.value: A power analysis is included in the pre-analysis plan for the January 2016 study.

attributes.title: Bypass Aid and Local Accountability Survey Experiment

q1.value: Bypass Aid and Local Accountability Survey Experiment

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: This project explores how citizens understand aid flows and, in particular, “bypass aid” (aid that flows to non-governmental organizations (NGOs), rather than to the government). Donors have promoted the distribution of aid directly to NGOs and service providers as a means of ensuring that aid reaches the needy in contexts where local government capacity is low. But what does this process signal to citizens about the quality of their local government? And do citizens believe that such bypass aid is more or less likely to help people in the district and to support the projects in which citizens are interested? The distribution of aid directly to NGOs and service providers, rather than through the government, has been advocated as a means by which foreign aid donors can mitigate problems associated with weak governance. By sidestepping low-capacity governments, donors may be able to better assist needy citizens (Dietrich 2013, 2016; Winters 2010, 2014). Yet the decision by donors to provide aid to NGOs rather than the local government may also communicate information to citizens about the quality of government. On the one hand, insofar as citizens indicate preferences for and greater willingness to support projects described as being funded by donors (Milner, Nielson and Findley 2013), aid to NGOs may increase citizens’ perceptions of the quality of both services and the government (Dietrich and Winters 2015, Sachs 2011). On the other hand, insofar as citizens believe either that governments are less relevant to service delivery when aid is delivered to NGOs or that donors’ decisions to bypass governments are a result of poor governance, bypass aid may increase citizens’ perceptions of the quality of service delivery but lower their perceptions of the quality of governance. We will test these hypotheses using a survey experiment conducted on a random sample of adults in 8 parishes in Eastern and Western Uganda. Specifically, we manipulate the amount of information provided to citizens about aid to specific district in Uganda understand what citizens infer from learning about aid flows in general and about aid flows that either do or do not bypass the government.

q16.value: Aid flows to a district might either signal that the local government is in need of foreign assistance (and therefore of lower quality) or else that the government is worthy of support (and therefore of higher quality). 1a. Respondents will believe district governments to be of lower quality when a district receives an increase in aid. 1b. Respondents will believe district governments to be of higher quality when a district receives an increase in aid. Similarly, respondents might either believe that aid helps a government to improve its quality or else they might think that the flow of foreign funds undermines the quality of the government. 2a. Respondents will believe district governments will become lower quality when a district receives an increase in aid. 2b. Respondents will believe district governments will become higher quality when a district receives an increase in aid. Based on previous results in the literature from Uganda (Milner, Nielson, and Findley 2013), we expect respondents to believe that aid does more good and is more responsive to citizens’ needs when it is channeled through NGOs: 3. Respondents will believe aid projects to be of higher quality when aid is channeled to NGOs versus the district government. The flow of aid to NGOs rather than to the government might lead citizens to believe – as would seem to be the correct inference given results in the literature (Dietrich 2013, 2016) – that donors are bypassing a low-quality government. On the other hand, it is possible that citizens will draw the opposite inference, thinking that the government is of sufficient quality that it does not need funds from foreign donors, leading those donors to give money through NGOs. 4a. Respondents will believe district governments to be of lower quality when aid is channeled to NGOs versus the district government. 4b. Respondents will believe district governments to be of higher quality when aid is channeled to NGOs versus the district government. Just as overall aid flows might be perceived either as helping a government to improve its quality or else as undermining the quality of the government, we also expect the mention of the explicit channeling of the funding through the government to elicit such inferences. 5a. Respondents will believe district governments will become lower quality when aid is channeled to NGOs versus the district government. 5b. Respondents will believe district governments will become higher quality when aid is channeled to NGOs versus the district government.

q17.value: We will test these hypotheses using a survey experiment conducted on a random sample of adults in 8 parishes in Eastern and Western Uganda. There will be four arms of our survey experiment. In each arm, respondents will be asked to reflect on the amount of aid going to a distant district in Northern Uganda. Importantly, this district received an increase in aid to both NGOs and the district government between 2012 and 2013. The survey experiment will vary the amount of information respondents are given on this increase. Group 1: No info on increase over time. "As you may know, many countries in the world send large amounts of foreign aid to Uganda. This money is often intended to be spent on things like schools and health clinics to help the people of Uganda. Different amounts of money go to different districts in Uganda in different years. We are going to tell you some information about international aid to one particular district in Northern Uganda, Yumbe District, which is much like many districts in this part of the country. Afterwards we are going to ask you to tell us what you think about the international aid going to this district. Please do your best to answer these questions, as we are interested in what you think even if you do not know the answer for sure. In 2012, Yumbe District in Northern Uganda received some aid." Group 2: Info on aid increase to unspecified recipient. "As you may know, many countries in the world send large amounts of foreign aid to Uganda. This money is often intended to be spent on things like schools and health clinics to help the people of Uganda. Different amounts of money go to different districts in Uganda in different years. We are going to tell you some information about international aid to one particular district in Northern Uganda, Yumbe District, which is much like many districts in this part of the country. Afterwards we are going to ask you to tell us what you think about the international aid going to this district. Please do your best to answer these questions, as we are interested in what you think even if you do not know the answer for sure. In 2012, Yumbe District in Northern Uganda received some aid. Between 2012 and 2013, the amount of aid going to Yumbe District increased a lot." Group 3: Info on aid increase to government. "As you may know, many countries in the world send large amounts of foreign aid to Uganda. This money is often intended to be spent on things like schools and health clinics to help the people of Uganda. Different amounts of money go to different districts in Uganda in different years. We are going to tell you some information about international aid to one particular district in Northern Uganda, Yumbe District, which is much like many districts in this part of the country. Afterwards we are going to ask you to tell us what you think about the international aid going to this district. Please do your best to answer these questions, as we are interested in what you think even if you do not know the answer for sure. In 2012, Yumbe District in Northern Uganda received some aid. Between 2012 and 2013, the amount of aid going to Yumbe District increased a lot, and money was given to the district government." Group 4: Info on aid increase to NGOs. "As you may know, many countries in the world send large amounts of foreign aid to Uganda. This money is often intended to be spent on things like schools and health clinics to help the people of Uganda. Different amounts of money go to different districts in Uganda in different years. We are going to tell you some information about international aid to one particular district in Northern Uganda, Yumbe District, which is much like many districts in this part of the country. Afterwards we are going to ask you to tell us what you think about the international aid going to this district. Please do your best to answer these questions, as we are interested in what you think even if you do not know the answer for sure. In 2012, Yumbe District in Northern Uganda received some aid. Between 2012 and 2013, the amount of aid going to Yumbe District increased a lot, and money was given to NGOs in the district." We are interested in the effects of information about aid to NGOs versus aid to the local government on citizens’ perceptions of the quality and responsiveness of aid projects and the quality of government. We have multiple measures of each outcome, and also questions designed to assess whether the effect of aid on perceptions of governance is due to the information aid signals about governance or the presumed effects of aid on governance. A. Quality of aid projects First, we are interested in seeing whether respondents think differently about aid that goes through the government versus aid that goes to NGOs. We ask two questions to measure respondents’ perceptions of the quality of aid. 1. Aid Benefits: How many people respondents think foreign aid has benefited in Yumbe (None of them, some of them, most of them, all of them) 2. Aid Responsiveness: How likely respondents think it is that foreign aid to Yumbe has been spent on the projects that the people of Yumbe wanted most (Very likely, somewhat likely, somewhat unlikely, very unlikely) B. Quality of government B1. Aid as Signal of Government Quality Do citizens make inferences about their local governments depending on whether it is receiving increased aid and whether that increased aid is going to the district government or else is going to NGOs in the district? We look at four outcomes: two related to the respondents’ perceptions of the district government in question, and two related to how respondents perceive likely levels of compliance behavior among citizens in the district. 1. Performance: How well respondents think the government of Yumbe was performing in 2012 (Very well, somewhat well, somewhat poorly, very poorly) 2. Corruption: How many people in the district administration in Yumbe respondents think were involved in corruption in 2012 (None of them, some of them, most of them, all of them) 3. Compliance (I): The district government in Yumbe is responsible for collecting fees for business licenses, market stands and other such things. What proportion of people in Yumbe district do you think actually paid the fees they owed the district in 2012? (None of them, few of them, some of them, most of them) 4. Compliance (II): The district government in Yumbe is responsible for organizing community meetings on important public health issues. How many people in Yumbe district do you think actually attended the meetings on public health issues organized by the district government in 2012? (None of them, few of them, some of them, most of them) B2. Aid as Cause of Governance Quality Do citizens believe that aid will change government behavior and citizen interactions with government? We assess this by measuring respondents’ perceptions of how government quality and citizen compliance will have changed over time in the wake of increasing aid flows. 1. Performance: In the past three years, do you think performance of the district administration in Yumbe district has increased or declined? (Increased, no change, declined) 2. Corruption: In the past three years, do you think the number of people in the district administration in Yumbe involved in corruption has increased or declined? (Increased, no change, declined) 3. Compliance (I): In the past three years, do you think the number of people in Yumbe district who are have actually participated in clean-up campaigns to remove garbage has increased or decreased? (Increased, no change, declined) 4. Compliance (II): In the past three years, do you think the number of people in Yumbe district who attended public health meetings organized by the district government has increased or decreased? (Increased, no change, declined) We will test hypotheses 1 and 2 by comparing outcomes in Group 1 to outcomes in Groups 2 and 2, 3, and 4. We will test hypotheses 3, 4 and 5 by comparing outcomes in Group 3 and Group 4. Our baseline analysis will be an OLS regression that includes dummy variables for each strata. In addition, we will run an OLS regression that also includes basic socio-demographic characteristics (age, gender, education, religion, occupation and three need-based measures of household well-being). Finally, we will calculate the complier average treatment effect by using the treatments as instruments for whether the respondent believed (a) aid to the district had increased between 2012 and 2013 and (b) the main recipient of aid was NGOs versus the government.

attributes.title: Bypass Aid and Local Accountability Informational Intervention

q1.value: Bypass Aid and Local Accountability Informational Intervention

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: This project seeks to understand the effects of “bypass aid” (aid that flows to non-governmental organizations (NGOs), rather than to the government) on the ability and willingness of citizens to hold service providers accountable, the ability and willingness of citizens to hold politicians accountable, and the legitimacy that citizens attach to government institutions. Although the distribution of aid directly to NGOs and service providers has been advocated as a means of ensuring that aid reaches the needy in contexts where local government capacity is low, this type of aid may have unintended consequences on local government capacity and accountability. We will examine these possible consequences of bypass aid through an informational intervention in eight sub-counties in Uganda. The intervention varies whether adults are informed of the true implementer and funder of local projects. The informational intervention will allow us to assess whether adults who are informed that a project is donor-funded and/or NGO-implemented express different beliefs about the quality of and likelihood of accountability in the project, the performance of their local politicians, and the legitimacy of their local government as compared to otherwise similar adults who lack this information.

q16.value: We generally expect that revealing information about projects will have positive effects on our outcomes related to service accessibility, assessments of local politicians and government legitimacy. We also expect that revealing a project is foreign-funded or NGO-implemented should increase perceptions of project quality and service accessibility. However, we can imagine that revealing that a project is foreign-funded or NGO-implemented could have either a positive or a negative effect on the means of accountability in the project, the assessments of local politicians, and the legitimacy of the local government. We list our hypotheses below. The rationale behind them is explained in more detail in the hypotheses section of the attached pre-analysis plan. Perceptions of the Project and Service Accessibility We expect that the perceptions of service accessibility will be higher in all conditions where respondents learn about a project. We expect that perceptions of service accessibility and project quality will be higher in the conditions where respondents learn about foreign donor funding and/or NGO implementation. Project Accountability and Project Engagement It is ambiguous whether learning a project is NGO implemented or donor funded will increase or decrease the willingness of citizens to take action if the project experiences problems. Electoral Accountability We expect citizens who hear about a project to be more supportive of local politicians than those who do not receive information about a project. It is ambiguous whether citizens who learn a project is donor-funded and/or NGO-implemented will be more or less supportive of local politicians. We expect the amount of support politicians receive when citizens receive information about a project to be conditional on politicians’ perceived and real levels of involvement with the project. Government Legitimacy We expect citizens who hear about a project to view their governments as more legitimate than citizens who do not. It is ambiguous whether citizens who learn a project is donor-funded and/or NGO-implemented will view their government as more or less legitimate.

q17.value: This study is concerned with the effect on accountability of foreign aid that bypasses governments. Our research design involves an informational intervention that will vary the amount of information provided to different respondents about the funding sources and implementing partners for local development projects in their communities. Citizens in Uganda typically have a great deal of uncertainty about funding sources and implementing organizations for local development projects (Milner, Nielson and Findley 2013). As a result, by revealing the true source of funding and the true implementing partner to randomly selected citizens, we will be able to change some citizens’ beliefs about the groups responsible for funding and implementing local projects. The information to be distributed in the study comes from three sources: (1) the Uganda Aid Management Platform, which is overseen by the Aid Liaison Office at the Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development (MoFPED) with assistance from USAID/Uganda and the AidData Initiative; (2) the website of the Embassy of Japan in Uganda; and (3) advance surveys with NGO officials and political elites in the study areas. The sub-counties included in the study are all home to development interventions funded by Japan’s Grant Assistance for Grassroots Human Security Projects (GGP) and implemented by non-governmental organizations. We have included sub-counties that received grants between 2012 and 2015. In each of eight sub-counties, we will first select the parish in which the project is based (or that is reported to benefit most from the project). Then we will randomly select half of the polling stations in this parish for inclusion in the study. We will randomly select households in these polling stations, and then interview either an adult male or an adult female who is at home at the time of the survey within the selected households. Respondents in the household survey will be randomly assigned to one of five treatment groups indicated below; the randomization will be stratified by sub-county and gender. (A1) No information about project prior to measurement of service accessibility, electoral accountability, and government legitimacy outcomes (B1) Information about project but no attribution of responsibility for funding or implementation (B2) Information about project and source of funding but no information about implementation (B3) Information about project and institution responsible for implementation but no information about funding (B4) Information about project, funding source, and institution responsible for implementation Individuals assigned to treatment group (A1) will be told nothing about the project until after we have measured the outcome variables related to service accessibility, electoral accountability and government legitimacy and will therefore serve as a pure control. After measuring outcomes, we will tell them about the project only – as in B1 – and solicit their beliefs about the funding source and implementing partner at that time. Individuals assigned to treatment groups (B1 – B4) will be told something like this : “A project to construct a girls' dormitory block at Bukooli College, as well as to construct latrines and provide water tanks, began in this district in 2013. The project cost around 350 million Ugandan shilling, and it occurred in this parish. Here is a photo of the dormitories that were constructed as a result of this project.” As indicated, we also will show a photograph of the project in question to the respondents. Immediately after hearing this information and seeing the image, we will solicit from these individuals their perceptions of the project. We will ask them: (1) Before I gave you this information, had you previously heard of this project? (2) Who do you think funded the project? (3) Who do you think was in charge of managing the funds and using them to run the project? Individuals assigned to treatment group (A1) also will receive this information, see the photo, and be asked about their perceptions of the project but only after they already have answered the questions operationalizing our outcome variables related to service accessibility, electoral accountability and government legitimacy. Observations in this cell will be pooled with cell B1 for the purposes of analyzing the outcomes related to the perceptions of project quality and project accountability so long as we do not detect section ordering effects. For individuals assigned to treatment group (B1), there is no further treatment, and we will proceed to ask them the outcome questions. This group, therefore, serves as a control group that has been exposed to information about a project and that has been asked about their views of who funded and implemented the project but that has not been told the true information about funding and implementation. Individuals assigned to treatment group (B2) will be told the initial information and asked their beliefs about funding and implementation. Then they will be given additional information about funding in a form something like this: “I wanted to give you some additional information about the groups involved in providing the project to construct a girls' dormitory block at Bukooli College, as well as to construct latrines and provide water tanks. The Funding for the project came from Japan. Here is a photo of the Japanese ambassador signing off on funding.” As indicated, they will see an image of a Japanese official signing a document. This image will be the same for all projects. Individuals assigned to treatment group (B3) will be told the initial information and asked their beliefs about funding and implementation. Then they will be given additional information about implementation in a form something like this: “I wanted to give you some additional information about the groups involved in providing the project to construct a girls' dormitory block at Bukooli College, as well as to construct latrines and provide water tanks. The organization responsible for managing the projects funds and using them to run the project was the organization Bukooli College. Here is a photo of the signboard for the organization.” As indicated, these respondents will see an image representing the implementing organization (i.e., the sign outside the office of the organization). These images will be collected during interviews with officials from the implementing organizations. Individuals assigned to treatment group (B4) will be told the initial information and asked their beliefs about funding and implementation. Then they will be given additional information about funding and implementation in a form something like this: “I wanted to give you some additional information about the groups involved in providing the project to construct a girls' dormitory block at Bukooli College, as well as to construct latrines and provide water tanks. The Funding for the project came from Japan. Here is a photo of the Japanese ambassador signing off on funding. The organization responsible for managing the projects funds and using them to run the project was the organization Bukooli College. Here is a photo of the signboard for the organization.” As indicated, respondents in this treatment condition will see both the photo of the Japanese embassy official and of the implementing organization’s signboard. Importantly, the information revealed in each community will reflect the true funder and the true implementing partner for all projects (i.e., the treatments do not involve deception). Our sample of communities includes only communities with projects funded through the GGP grant-giving mechanism of the Japanese Embassy. This allows us to hold the funder and the amount of funding for each project constant, while the implementing partner will vary by community. Prior to conducting the informational intervention, we will conduct elite surveys with (a) the leaders of the organizations that received the grants and (b) LC3 councilors in each of the parishes in which we will conduct the informational intervention. These interviews will be used to guide site selection and to develop the informational prompts. After providing respondents with the informational treatment to which they are assigned, we will ask questions designed to measure our main outcomes of interest. Our main research questions relate to the effect of bypass aid on subjects’ willingness and ability to provide oversight of projects, their evaluations of local politicians and their perceptions of the legitimacy of local government. In addition, we examine the effects of bypass aid on perceptions of project quality and service accessibility. We indicate the specific questions we will use to measure each outcome in the Outcome Measures section of the attached pre-analysis plan. For each of our hypotheses, we are interested in estimating two effects – the average treatment effect across all subjects and the average treatment effect on compliers (subjects whose information was changed as a result of the informational intervention). For example, all subjects may have priors about project funding and project implementation. They may believe that the project was funded by the national government, the local government, an NGO, a foreign donor, or some other entity – or they may not know. They may believe that the project was implemented by the national government, the local government, an NGO, a foreign donor, or some other entity – or they may not know. Some people will have correct and certain priors, and some people will have incorrect or uncertain priors. We solicit these priors in all treatment conditions immediately after we describe the project. For individuals with certain and correct priors, our treatments may still have an effect via priming, but to isolate the priming from the informational effect, we will analyze effects both over the full sample and over the sample with incorrect or diffuse priors. Similarly, some individuals may have the project in mind ex ante and some may not have the project in mind. Our survey also includes a question designed to measure this, and we can examine the effect of information about the project across both the whole sample and the subset of the sample who did not have the project in mind ex ante. We will test our hypotheses related to learning about a project by comparing the differences between subjects in the following treatment arms: Effect of learning about a project: A1 vs. B1 (B2, B3, B4) Effect of learning about a donor-funded project: A1 vs. B2, B4 Effect of learning about an NGO-implemented project: A1 vs. B3, B4 We will test our hypotheses related to the differential effects of government-funded versus donor-funded and government-implemented versus NGO-implemented projects by comparing the differences between subjects in the following treatment arms: Effect of learning a project was donor-funded: B1 vs. B2, B4 Effect of learning a project was NGO-implemented: B1 vs. B3, B4 Our main tests will involve running OLS regression analyses with fixed effects for each strata. We will also run OLS regression analyses with controls for basic socio-demographic characteristics (age, gender, education, religion, occupation and three need-based measures of household well-being). For the electoral accountability outcome measures, we will also include controls for political party identification and past voting behavior. For the government legitimacy outcome measures, we will control for whether or not the household has paid fees to the local government in the past.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: This project seeks to understand the effects of “bypass aid” (aid that flows to non-governmental organizations (NGOs), rather than to the government) on the ability and willingness of citizens to hold service providers accountable, the ability and willingness of citizens to hold politicians accountable, and the legitimacy that citizens attach to government institutions. Although the distribution of aid directly to NGOs and service providers has been advocated as a means of ensuring that aid reaches the needy in contexts where local government capacity is low, this type of aid may have unintended consequences on local government capacity and accountability. We will examine these possible consequences of bypass aid through an informational intervention in eight sub-counties in Uganda. The intervention varies whether adults are informed of the true implementer and funder of local projects. The informational intervention will allow us to assess whether adults who are informed that a project is donor-funded and/or NGO-implemented express different beliefs about the quality of and likelihood of accountability in the project, the performance of their local politicians, and the legitimacy of their local government as compared to otherwise similar adults who lack this information.
registration_responses.q16: We generally expect that revealing information about projects will have positive effects on our outcomes related to service accessibility, assessments of local politicians and government legitimacy. We also expect that revealing a project is foreign-funded or NGO-implemented should increase perceptions of project quality and service accessibility. However, we can imagine that revealing that a project is foreign-funded or NGO-implemented could have either a positive or a negative effect on the means of accountability in the project, the assessments of local politicians, and the legitimacy of the local government. We list our hypotheses below. The rationale behind them is explained in more detail in the hypotheses section of the attached pre-analysis plan. Perceptions of the Project and Service Accessibility We expect that the perceptions of service accessibility will be higher in all conditions where respondents learn about a project. We expect that perceptions of service accessibility and project quality will be higher in the conditions where respondents learn about foreign donor funding and/or NGO implementation. Project Accountability and Project Engagement It is ambiguous whether learning a project is NGO implemented or donor funded will increase or decrease the willingness of citizens to take action if the project experiences problems. Electoral Accountability We expect citizens who hear about a project to be more supportive of local politicians than those who do not receive information about a project. It is ambiguous whether citizens who learn a project is donor-funded and/or NGO-implemented will be more or less supportive of local politicians. We expect the amount of support politicians receive when citizens receive information about a project to be conditional on politicians’ perceived and real levels of involvement with the project. Government Legitimacy We expect citizens who hear about a project to view their governments as more legitimate than citizens who do not. It is ambiguous whether citizens who learn a project is donor-funded and/or NGO-implemented will view their government as more or less legitimate.
